title: HIV and Domestic Violence

content: Have you heard of IPV? It stands for intimate partner violence, a danger that too many women and people with HIV experience regularly.

Violence is associated with HIV, often upon first disclosure of an HIV status. But the lingering threat of violence can also exist in some relationships. Violence that hangs over your head and is difficult to escape, especially when you live with HIV.
Because your disease is used to manipulate you.
“Who else is going to love you with that disease?”
“No one else will ever love you.”
The saddest part is, they’re mostly right.

Dating is nearly impossible when you live with HIV because of pervasive stigma. A stigma that no longer holds any basis in truth. Medicine has greatly advanced since the introduction of antiretroviral (ARTs) drugs in 1996, but stigma continues to exist – even without facts.
This leads to extreme loneliness that often accompanies HIV. That can lead to depression, anxiety, and suicidal thoughts.

content: Wraparound services – like getting help with housing, childcare, transportation, and other resources – can be extremely limited when you have HIV. That’s because funding is extremely limited for HIV health care providers.
This means people may stop taking care of themselves and end their HIV treatment. Because someone who doesn’t have a home, food, and other necessities isn’t going to care about their HIV status.
These services aren’t a luxury, they’re essential. But so is safety.
It’s sometimes difficult to find empathy for people with HIV because fears of the disease can be stronger than compassion. That's always been true, from the beginning of the AIDS epidemic to now.
The default public perception of HIV is irrational fear. The fear was once justifiable, but no longer.

So, it can be hard to leave a relationship, even when it’s abusive. I know this because I’ve been in an abusive relationship.I struggled for years to liberate myself from it. I feared loneliness as much as my abuse. I feared my abusive partner more than my disease. I feared no one would believe me or care about my abuse, I feared I couldn’t find support or safety. I feared my partner's retribution.

content: Leaving was more frightening than staying. This is a trap too many people find themselves in.

The good news is, there are people and organizations who help people needing freedom from abusive situations.These are people who can be trusted. They’re just a Google search away. You don’t have to do this alone or stay in abuse. You deserve so much better.
If you or someone you know is in an abusive relationship, call the National Domestic Violence Hotline for confidential help anytime night or day at 800-799-7233 (SAFE). Or text BEGIN to 88788.
